Economist David Ricardo's theory of comparative advantage explains how countries trade today, emphasizing specialization and mutual benefits even if a country is more efficient in producing all goods. Ricardo argued that the opportunity cost, not just the absolute cost of production, determines whether specialization and trade should occur. Ricardo argued that comparing absolute costs of production between countries is less relevant for determining specialization and trade due to immobile resources. Instead, the focus should be on opportunity cost - the output forgone to produce one more unit of a good. Countries have a comparative advantage in goods with lower opportunity costs, leading to gains from trade through specialization.
